In reply please refer to :
Prière de rappeler la référence : C. L. 17. 1957
23 July 1957
各种得她生意,流行性感 供货許す性生活
指道是未到战场流行的花草目
I have the honour to inform you that data reported by a number of laboratories confirm that the current epidemic of influenza is due to a type of influenza A virus different from all previously isolated influenza viruses. The limited tests so far carried out indicate that the great part of populations tested have no specific immunity to the new strain and for this reason it is anticipated that the epidemic is likely to spread widely throughout the world. :selected:
It is already known or suspected that the virus is seeded widely in many parts of the world. Its presence has been officially reported in air passengers arriving from the affected area and in localized outbreaks in the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and the United States of America. It has been identified in outbreaks on ships in the North Atlantic and in certain European ports. It must be assumed to have been introduced into most countries with extensive air or sea communications with the epidemic area. However, so far local spread has been limited and it cannot be foreseen when the disease will appear in epidemic form in areas as yet unaffected.
All reports received indicate that the clinical disease to date remains mild and does not differ significantly from the clinical influenza experienced in recent years. Nevertheless, in the affected areas in Asia it has spread rapidly and widely affecting a large proportion of populations.
The Director Department of Health Administration Ministry of Interior Taipeh Taiwan
Republic of China
cc : Dr J. Heng Liu, Director, China Office ABMAC, Taipeh
Dr C. H. Yen, Department of Health, Taiwan Provincial Government, Taipeh Dr C. T. Loo, Deputy Director-General, National Defence Medical College, Taipeh

I have the honour to inform you that data reported by a number of laboratories confirm that the current epidemic of influenza is due to a type of influenza A virus different from all previously isolated influenza viruses. The limited tests so far carried out indicate that the great part of populations tested have no specific immunity to the new strain and for this reason it is anticipated that the epidemic is likely to spread widely throughout the world. :selected:

It is already known or suspected that the virus is seeded widely in many parts of the world. Its presence has been officially reported in air passengers arriving from the affected area and in localized outbreaks in the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and the United States of America. It has been identified in outbreaks on ships in the North Atlantic and in certain European ports. It must be assumed to have been introduced into most countries with extensive air or sea communications with the epidemic area. However, so far local spread has been limited and it cannot be foreseen when the disease will appear in epidemic form in areas as yet unaffected.

All reports received indicate that the clinical disease to date remains mild and does not differ significantly from the clinical influenza experienced in recent years. Nevertheless, in the affected areas in Asia it has spread rapidly and widely affecting a large proportion of populations.
